[{"type": "banner_image", "value": {"photo": null, "internal_link": null, "external_link": "", "alt_text": ""}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "Calling All Comrades!

Philadelphia DSA's Local Convention is fast approaching. After the landmark campaign of Bernie Sanders, the failure of Clintonite centrism, and the subsequent election of Donald Trump, DSA has seen explosive growth and our Local convention will be our largest in decades.

All members in good-standing are encouraged to attend the Convention and will enjoy voting rights. Members will vote on the future priorities of the Local, elect a new Steering Committee and elect delegates to the 2017 National DSA Convention. Non-members are welcome to attend as observers and encouraged to sign up to begin paying membership dues to receive a provisional ballot to participate.

Sign up to pay dues nationally and locally!

For more information and to learn about how to submit resolutions, bylaws amendments and how to run for an elected position please use this convention packet or contact Dustin at dustinfguastella@gmail.com.

Solidarity,

Philly DSA

"}, {"type": "banner_image", "value": {"photo": 7, "internal_link": null, "external_link": "", "alt_text": ""}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

¡Llamando a todos los camaradas!

La convención local de Philadelphia DSA se está acercando rápidamente. Después de la histórica campaña de Bernie Sanders, el fracaso del centrismo Clinton y la posterior elección de Donald Trump, la DSA ha experimentado un crecimiento explosivo y nuestra convención local será la más grande en décadas.

Se anima a todos los miembros de buena reputación a asistir a la Convención y gozarán de los derechos de voto. Los miembros votarán sobre las prioridades futuras del Local, elegirán un nuevo Comité Directivo y elegirán a los delegados a la Convención Nacional de DSA de 2017. Los no miembros son bienvenidos a asistir como observadores y se les anima a firmar para comenzar a pagar las cuotas de membresía para recibir una boleta provisional para participar.

¡Regístrese para pagar cuotas a nivel nacional y local!

Para obtener más información y para saber cómo presentar las resoluciones, enmiendas de los estatutos y cómo postularse para una posición elegida, por favor use este paquete de la Convención o póngase en contacto con Dustin en dustinfguastella@gmail.com. Echa un vistazo al paquete aquí.

Solidaridad,
Philly DSA

"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Conventioners!

Our Local Convention is just three days away!

Saturday, June 17th from 12:00-6:00 pm
First Unitarian Church
2125 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia

This email is both a reminder and debrief on what we will be discussing and voting on at our Convention. For more detailed information please see this (new and improved) Convention packet.

The Convention doors will open at 12:00 pm and registration will last one hour with our opening reports beginning at 1:00 pm. Members who have paid dues before June 12th will receive an official ballot upon registration. Members who have paid dues after June 12th will receive a provisional ballot to be counted later.

For those who are truly unable to attend, absentee balloting provisions will be announced shortly.

After registration and opening reports, members will have the opportunity to deliberate and debate in three sessions of floor voting:

  1. Bylaws amendments
  2. Resolutions
  3. National DSA Priorities

In particular, members will vote on whether Philly DSA commits to a Single-Payer / Medicare-for-All campaign for at least the next two years. Members will also debate and vote on electoral endorsement criteria for our Local.

In the final session, members will have an opportunity to debate DSA's National Priorities which are ultimately decided at our National Convention (August, 3-6). Following the debate, we will take a non-binding vote for our top three priorities.

After floor voting sessions, members will vote for a new Steering Committee and elect Delegates to the DSA National Convention by secret ballot.

For more on the convention schedule, ballots, resolutions and voting procedures please see the Convention Packet.

It's important that we have high attendance for this event! A robust convention is the mark of a strong organization, and the more members and energy we can stir up the better our debates will be.

Solidarity,
Dustin Guastella

"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

I’m sick and tired of being sick and tired.

-- Fanny Lou Hamer


Hello Philly DSA!

The Outreach Committee will be sending out two monthly bulletin emails, starting with this one. These emails have many different kinds of information for the Local, including actions, events, and announcements. Hopefully this will lessen the number of emails we send, and centralize the info you need as a member.

If you'd like to be involved with Outreach, contact David Backer at david.backer@gmail.com.


Bulletin At A Glance

  1. Message from the Co-chairs
  2. Our Local
  3. Upcoming events and actions
  4. General Meeting information


1. Message from the Co-chairs

Since our last general meeting, we’ve had several members come up with some great projects that our chapter to work on and for structures to make us more effective. So at our upcoming general meeting, we’ll be spending half our time hearing reportbacks on these plans and how members can get involved. We’ll also be reviewing proposals for a local campaign and electoral endorsements and we’ll have time for folks to talk to other members about these proposals in small groups. But to ensure that people have time to make an informed decision and to submit counter proposals, we’ll be holding off on voting until the following general meeting. Lets👏 get 👏 to 👏 work!


--Natalie & Adam


2. Our Local

Philadelphia DSA is volunteer-run and member-funded. Our organization relies on the commitment and consistent work of our members. Our Local structure consists of an elected Steering Committee, two Co-Chairs and several project based and task based committees. The following organizational chart demonstrates how these committees, the members and co-chairs relate to each other. In addition we encourage all members to read and become familiar with Philly DSA's Local Bylaws.




Members of the steering committee:

  • Natalie Midiri (co-chair),
  • Adam Goldman (co-chair),
  • Diane Isser,
  • Seth Kulick,
  • Paul Prescod,
  • Andrew Knox,
  • Joseph Schwartz,
  • Dustin Guastella.

Organizing Chairs: Sandra Lane, Sean Jin
Outreach Chair: David Backer
Political Education Chairs: Andrew Knox, Scott Jenkins
Childcare chair: Kat Edwards
Social Chair: Jedidiah Sloboda


3. Upcoming events and actions


Political Education

4/23 Jacobin reading group

The Jacobin Reading Group meets monthly to discuss selected readings from the most recent issue of Jacobin. Check back on the website/Philly DSA Facebook page for this month’s readings

4/26 ABCs of Socialism

Join us for the second session of Philly DSA's reading series on The ABCs of Socialism (click on the link, it’s the full text!) Published by Jacobin magazine in 2016, the ABC’s features essays on a wide range of political topics from a socialist perspective. We focus on a few different essays every month, this month we’ll be talking about:

  • Will socialists take away my Kenny Loggins records?

  • Doesn't socialism always end in dictatorship?

  • Is socialism a Western concept?


Canvassing for Larry Krasner - District Attorney Race

Reclaim Philadelphia has invited Philly DSA to join them in canvassing for progressive District Attorney candidate Larry Krasner.  Reclaim is organizing canvass across the city, Philly DSA members who would like to get involved should contact fellow Philly DSA member Jesse Kudler (jkudler@gmail.com). Some dates to keep in mind:


Tuesday, April 18th, 6-8pm

  • Phone bank to Sign DSA Members Up to Canvass for Krasner
  • Where: Natalie's house (1721 S. Mole St)
  • Text Natalie @ 609-238-4209 with questions or to rsvp

Saturday, April 15th, 12p-4p

South West Fishtown 1102 Ellsworth
633 League
2021 S. 13th Street
2208 Montrose Street 4416 Locust, Apt A
4916 Cedar Ave
5317 Catherine Street Palmier Park


Saturday, April 22, 12p-4p

South West North/Northeast 1102 Ellsworth
2021 S. 13th Street
805 E. Passyunk Avenue Locations TBD Locations TBD


Sunday, April 23, 12p-4p

South West Fishtown 2416 S. Sartain Street
1818 S. Broad Street 644 S. 54th Street
4800 Larchwood Avenue
4416 Locust, Apt A 2432 E. Norris Street


May Day/Day Without Immigrants (Día sin inmigrantes)

May 1st

Nationally, DSA has endorsed the Cosecha-organized Day Without Immigrants May Day Strike.

Check back on the website/Philly DSA Facebook page for more information about our local’s organized presence at May Day events in Philadelphia.


4. General Meeting Information

Date: 4/29, 1-4pm

Where: Church of the Advocate
1801 W Diamond St, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19121
Facebook event page
Agenda

This general meeting will look at proposals and reportbacks from various committees, as well as lay the foundation for a campaign vote in May (see "Message from the Chairs" above).

Now you can call it Single Payer, or the Canadian way
But only socialized medicine will ever save the day.
C’mon now, let me hear that dirty word:
Socialism!

--From Bulworth (1996)

"}]

[{"type": "banner_image", "value": {"photo": 11, "internal_link": null, "external_link": "", "alt_text": "DSA Posters - "Defund ICE", "No Wall", "No Ban""}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Hello DSAers! In the bulletin below we've got important information about our local convention, notes from the last general meeting, events and actions, and images from May Day.

¡Hola, DSAers! En nuestra boletín tenemos información importante sobre nuestra convención local, notas de la última reunión general, eventos y acciones, e imágenes del primer día. (En español abajo)

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "Our Local Convention FAQ"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "The local convention of Philly DSA is held every 2 years. The primary purpose is to elect our Steering Committee members, Co-Chairs, and Treasurer. We may also vote on various proposals (although proposals may be voted on at General Meetings as well) and announce delegates to the national convention. Follow this link for more information on logistics, rules, etc.


"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "General Meeting Notes"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Proposed Campaigns / Meeting Agenda Items

Scrap the Scrappers

Scrap yard owners in Kensington have gone too far, and the city government isn’t taking care of nearby working class residents’ needs. PlanPhilly reports on the high incidents of garbage, crime, sickness, and overall dilapidation in neighborhoods near Philadelphia Scrap Metal, K&A Auto Salvage, and Philadelphia Metal & Resource Recovery. This action will focus on the garbage these yards create and leave around the neighborhood, working with existing community organizations to use direct action and confront the owners of these scrap yards and their effect on the neighborhood.

Canvassing for Larry Krasner

Reclaim Philadelphia has invited Philly DSA members to join them in canvassing for progressive District Attorney candidate Larry Krasner. This race has gotten national attention and a progressive win in the DA’s office could have wider reverberations across the country. Reclaim is organizing canvassing efforts across the city in nearly every neighborhood. Philly DSA members who would like to get involved should contact fellow Philly DSA member Jesse Kudler (jkudler@gmail.com).

Additionally, don’t forget that Philly’s municipal elections are coming up on May 16th so make sure to get out to your polls and support our boy LK after you canvass for him!

Single Payer PA

At the next general meeting Philly DSA will vote (among dues paying members) whether or not we will support a Single Payer Healthcare campaign in PA. A bunch of great points were brought up in discussions and thoughtful questions were asked and we need your input! There will be more information about the details of this campaign including financial/legislative viability in PA, how it can help our organization gain visibility, and how we can broaden the conversation on this important issue. Check phillydsa.com soon!  

Support/Endorsements of Candidates

The last major item on the agenda is how and whether the Philly DSA should support candidates – or endorse them – or none of the above and what levels of support should candidates receive. The main distinction being whether or not candidates explicitly support the DSA and socialist policy initiatives or are merely progressive candidates with sympathetic political views. More on this will be on phillydsa.com ASAP.

Local Dues

Class struggle is more expensive than you’d think. You’ve got space rental for meetings, sign printing for marches, guillotine manufacturing for…this and that. So to help offset the cost of operations for the Philly DSA you can now pay dues directly to the local chapter. If you’re saying – hey, why did I get that card that I posted to Twitter when I became a dues paying member – you’re paying up to the National. This is to pay straight into the coffers of the local for costs related to the operation of the chapter. Contact us with questions and then give us your money!

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "Upcoming events and actions"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

by Theresa Moran

    5/4   DSA Movie Night – Matewan (1987)


Dig in to some labor history with Matewan! This month’s movie tells the story of the real-life coal miner’s strike in West Virginia in the 1920s that culminated in the Battle of Matewan and marked a crucial turning point for mineworker organizing in the United States.

    5/16 Jacobin Reading Group


The Jacobin Reading Group meets monthly to discuss selected readings from the most recent issue of Jacobin. Check out the website/Philly DSA Facebook page for this month’s readings

    5/21 ABCs of Socialism


Join us for Philly DSA's reading series on The ABCs of Socialism (click on the link, it’s the full text!) Published by Jacobin magazine in 2016, the ABC’s features essays on a wide range of political topics from a socialist perspective. We focus on a few different essays every month, this month we’ll be talking about:

    6/5 An Evening with Steve Early


Labor journalist Steve Early will be speaking about his latest book, Refinery Town: Big Oil, Big Money, and the Remaking of an American City. Refinery Town “chronicles the fifteen years of successful community organizing that raised the local minimum wage, defeated a casino development project, challenged home foreclosures and evictions, and sought fair taxation of Big Oil and Big Soda” in the city of Richmond, California. The talk will include lessons on how to organize broad-based campaigns for progressive gains here in Philadelphia.

Early is also the author of Embedded With Organized Labor: Journalistic Reflections on the Class War at Home; The Civil Wars in U.S. Labor: Birth of a New Workers’ Movement or Death Throes of the Old?; and Save Our Unions: Dispatches from a Movement in Distress

Organizing Training


    6/17  “What is Organizing? - How to Build Power”


This summer, Philly DSA’s Organizing Committee is launching a series of trainings open to the entire Philly DSA local to help members develop core organizing skills. This first session will focus on organizing basics. Future sessions will center on power mapping and on campaign strategies and tactics.

Committee Meetings

    5/3 Organizing Committee Meeting

    5/7 Political Education Committee meeting

    5/7 Mobilizers Planning Committee meeting

    The Outreach and Fundraising Committees will be deciding on May meeting dates later in the month – please check the website and Facebook page calendars for more information

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "Philly DSA @ May Day"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"photo": 12, "photo_alignment": "center", "caption": "Photo by Matt Slusser", "caption_alignment": "tl"}}, {"type": "image", "value": {"photo": 13, "photo_alignment": "center", "caption": "Photo by Matt Slusser", "caption_alignment": "tl"}}]

We\u2019re setting a benchmark of $5,000 by July 15th; it\u2019s a lot but we think we can get there!", "button_title": "Donate Today!", "button_link": null, "button_external_link": "https://chuffed.org/project/help-our-delegates-get-to-the-national-convention"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Look out for more updates from us soon!

"}]

[{"type": "call_to_action", "value": {"title": "We're Going to Chicago!", "cta_copy": "Philly DSA is sending our delegates to the National Convention and we need your help! We need to raise money so we can get there, eat some Chicago dogs, and help determine DSA's future!", "button_title": "Donate today!", "button_link": null, "button_external_link": "https://chuffed.org/project/help-our-delegates-get-to-the-national-convention"}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Philly DSA is a local chapter of the Democratic Socialists of America, the largest socialist organization in the US. We are a group of dues paying members who organize together for progressive change in Philadelphia to weaken the hold large corporations have on our government and build power for working class Americans.

"}, {"type": "block_quote", "value": {"quote": "As democratic socialists, we believe that both the economy and society should be run democratically — to meet public needs, not to make profits for an elite few."}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

To achieve this goal, we believe that many structures of our government and economy must be radically transformed through greater economic and social democracy so that ordinary Americans can have a say in how are lives are structured in the work-place, our schools, and neighborhoods.

"}, {"type": "block_quote", "value": {"quote": "In Philadelphia, we believe that our vision for a more just society begins with raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour, fully funding our public schools, and creating independent police review boards."}}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For more information about DSA, our democratic socialist vision, or to sign-up to become a member of DSA, visit our national website dsausa.org 

"}, {"type": "call_to_action", "value": {"title": "Join Philly DSA!", "cta_copy": "Sign Up to Join the Movement and Get Updates from our Activist List!", "button_title": "Join now!", "button_link": 11, "button_external_link": ""}}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

This month's readings (p. 70-115, you can access via this link -https://s3.jacobinmag.com/issues/jacobin-abcs.pdf):

  • \"What about racism? Don't socialists only care about class?\"
  • \"Aren't socialism and feminism sometimes in conflict?\"
  • \"Are socialists pacifists?\"

The events of the past year point to the re-emergence of socialism as a viable political force in America and global politics. Bernie Sanders mobilized millions of voters on a program of class struggle and redistribution and over the past six months the Democratic Socialists of America have tripled in size.

As a result many of our new members \u2014 and curious onlookers \u2014 are asking questions: Is socialism like Sweden? Will I have to stand in line to buy toilet paper under socialism? What do socialists think about racism and sexism?

Join DSA for a reading series on The ABC\u2019s of Socialism. Published by Jacobin magazine in 2016, the ABC\u2019s features essays on a wide range of political topics from a socialist perspective. We\u2019ll explore the history of the socialist idea, socialism and its relationship to capitalism and why socialists yammer on about the working class.


"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Philly DSA is training up a team of Mobilizers to be internal organizers for our membership. As a large AND GROWING organization, our goal is to build participatory democratic structures and establish clear channels of communication within the local. Becoming a Mobilizer will also give members an opportunity to get more involved in building our local DSA chapter!

Each Mobilizer will get a \u201cturf\u201d of about 10 other Philly DSA members who they will keep in contact with through texts, emails, phone calls, and in-person meetings. We expect the time commitment to be about 10 hours per month. The main role of Mobilizers will be to:

  • Orient Philly DSA members to the structure of the local, our shared politics, our committees, and our campaign work
  • Answer questions and connect people to resources, committees, and other members
  • Do personal outreach to keep people informed of upcoming events and actions
  • Facilitate \u201cbottom up\u201d communication between the general membership of Philly DSA and the Steering Committee
  • Lead canvasses and acting as canvass captains for future campaign work
"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Join us for a book talk and discussion with Steve Early, author of Refinery Town: Big Oil, Big Money, and the Remaking of an American City and Mary Adamson from the Pennsylvania Association of Staff Nurses & Allied Professionals to discuss how the Left can build grassroots coalitions to win elections, shape left-wing policy, and build living local alternatives to Trump's agenda.


In Refinery Town, Early traces the birth and growth of the Richmond Progressive Alliance as it came to challenge the Chevron Corporation, the city's largest private employer, and its iron grip on the city's politics. In 2016, the RPA won a majority on the city council, along with rent control and just cause for eviction in a bitter fight with the city's realtor groups. Their struggle to build a winning electoral coalition, rooted in social movements and unafraid to challenge the city's corporate interests, holds valuable lessons for socialists trying to do the same in Philadelphia.

Steve Early has worked as a labor journalist, lawyer, organizer, or union representative since 1972. For 27 years, Early was a Boston-based national staff member of the Communications Workers of America. Early has been a resident of Richmond, CA for the last five years. He is a member of the Richmond Progressive Alliance and serves as an appointed member of the city Personnel Board, a body which hears municipal employee grievances.


Mary Adamson is a registered nurse with over 20 years' experience in Critical Care, primarily Trauma ICU. She serves on the executive committee as Membership Secretary for Temple University Hospital Nurses Association, a local of PASNAP.


Check out Refinery Town here: http://www.beacon.org/Refinery-Town-P1229.aspx

"}]

Please note that this event will be in the BASEMENT of Chapterhouse Cafe

As a result many of our new members \u2014 and curious onlookers \u2014 are asking questions: Is socialism like Sweden? Will I have to stand in line to buy toilet paper under socialism? What do socialists think about racism and sexism?

Join DSA for a reading series on The ABC\u2019s of Socialism. Published by Jacobin magazine in 2016, the ABC\u2019s features essays on a wide range of political topics from a socialist perspective. We\u2019ll explore the history of the socialist idea, socialism and its relationship to capitalism and why socialists yammer on about the working class.

You can access the full text here:\u00a0https://s3.jacobinmag.com/issues/jacobin-abcs.pdf:

At the Local Convention dues-paying members will elect the new Steering Committee and the Delegation to the National DSA Convention (August 3-6 2017, in Chicago). Further, members will vote from the floor on amendments to the Bylaws and Proposals and Resolutions submitted to the membership.

fields.intro: Here's a list of our upcoming events.

fields.body:
[{"type": "subhead", "value": "What is Philly DSA’s Organizational Structure?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Because DSA nationally is what we call a broad-tent “multitendency” organization, we have no holy books or martyrs. There is no one essay or strategy article you must read and agree with to be a DSA member. In fact, we draw our strength from the diversity of our ideas and our rigorous commitment to democratic practice.

Stemming from this, our local has full autonomy to decide on projects and campaigns based upon our assessment of the local political climate, our community partners, and membership’s interests and needs. We do not receive marching orders from DSA’s national leadership, rather we work to democratically decide as a local what our work should be and DSA’s national leadership works to poll locals to create national priorities.

DSA holds a national convention every two years that is open to all members where we join together to vote on priorities and to elect the National Political Committee (NPC), the board of members who steer the organization in between conventions.

Philly DSA also holds a convention every two years, usually just before the national convention, where we also vote on priorities, elect delegates to the national convention, and elect our local Steering Committee, the board that runs the local.

We have a monthly General Membership Meeting where committees report back on their work and committees may meet more frequently in between monthly meetings. 

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "How do members of the local keep in touch with each other? How can I communicate with the whole group?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Philly DSA Activist Listserv (Philly-DSA-Activist@googlegroups.com) is the main way to keep in touch with our active members. This is the list we use to coordinate local work, share articles, and pass on info about upcoming events.

If you don’t mind getting a few Philly DSA emails every day, you can sign up here to join the listserv but don’t worry, even if you don’t we’ll make sure we reach out to you with information on official Philly DSA events.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "What are Philly DSA's committees?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Philly DSA’s Steering Committee is the democratically elected body that steers the organization in between Conventions and General Meetings. Currently, our Steering Committee includes two (2) Co-Chairs and six (6) At-Large members.

In addition to the Steering Committe, Philly DSA also has 3 other committees and may grow to develop more. If you would like to get involved with one of the committees, please reach out to the Chair of the committee for information.

  • Organizing: Brittany Alston (co-chair) and Anthony Hawkins (co-chair)
  • Outreach: David Backer
  • Political Education: Andrew Knox and Scott Jenkins
  • Childcare: Kat Edwards
  • Social Chair: Jedidiah Sloboda
  • Fundraising: Jordan Falciani
  • Mobilizers: Theresa Moran

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "I have an idea for a project I’d like Philly DSA to work on. Where should I start?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

That depends.

If you have an idea for a project that might fall under the umbrella of one of our existing committees it would be best to email the chair of the committee or attend one of the committee meetings to propose your idea.

For example, you’d like to start a reading group on Das Kapital or the History of the Russian Revolution? Great! Talk to the political education committee.

If you have an idea for a project that doesn’t already have a team working in that area, please email the Steering Committee (phillysteeringcommittee@googlegroups.com) so that they can help you draft a proposal to bring the idea before the local or help connect you with other members who may be interested in the work too.

If you would like to propose a campaign for the local, please fill out this Campaign Proposal Form and return it to the Steering Committee.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "Does Philly DSA have a process for responding to discrimination, harassment, predatory behavior or other misconduct within the local?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

In the event of misconduct within the local, please reach out directly to one of the chairs,  Adam or Natalie.

The issue will be reviewed by the Steering Committee and the committee will take steps to protect the privacy of the members involved and rectify the situation to the best of our abilities, which may include:

  • Mediating a conversation between members
  • Developing a written action plan outlining prohibited behaviors and reviewing it privately with members
  • Suspending or terminating membership

Any person whose membership has been suspended or terminated may appeal the decision before the general membership at a meeting of the full local.

"}]

[{"type": "subhead", "value": "Organizational Chart"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Philadelphia DSA is volunteer-run and member-funded. Our organization relies on the commitment and consistent work of our members. Our Local structure consists of an elected Steering Committee, two Co-Chairs and several project based and task based committees. The following organizational chart demonstrates how these committees, the members and co-chairs relate to each other. In addition we encourage all members to read and become familiar with Philly DSA's Local Bylaws.

"}, {"type": "image", "value": {"photo": 5, "photo_alignment": "center", "caption": "The DSA's Organizational Chart", "caption_alignment": "tl"}}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "Committees"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Steering Committee is made up of:

  • Natalie Midiri (co-chair),
  • Adam Goldman (co-chair),
  • Diane Isser,
  • Seth Kulick,
  • Paul Prescod,
  • Andrew Knox,
  • Joseph Schwartz, and
  • Dustin Guastella.

Organizing Chairs: Brittany Alston (co-chair) and Anthony Hawkins (co-chair)
Outreach Chair: David Backer
Political Education Chairs: Andrew Knox and Scott Jenkins
Childcare chair: Kat Edwards
Social Chair: Jedidiah Sloboda
Fundraising: Jordan Falciani
Mobilizers: Theresa Moran

"}, {"type": "call_to_action", "value": {"title": "Join the Philly DSA", "cta_copy": "Sign Up to Join the Movement and Get Updates from our Activist List!", "button_title": "Join the movement!", "button_link": 11, "button_external_link": ""}}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

For general questions about getting involved with Philly DSA or our events contact one of our Co-Chairs,\u00a0Natalie or Adam.\u00a0

  • Natalie Midiri
  • Adam Goldman

Or follow us on Twitter or Facebook!


"}]

[{"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Are you looking for a way to fight the corporate power structure guiding a misguided system? Do you think capitalism is an exploitative and unfair system rigged to help the ultra-wealthy? Do you think Leftist Twitter is the Bestest Twitter? Well (if you’re in Philadelphia or the surrounding area) have we got an opportunity for you!

"}, {"type": "call_to_action", "value": {"title": "Join the National DSA & Become a Member of the Local!", "cta_copy": "By joining the national DSA, you automatically become a voting member of the PhillyDSA local. After signing up, check out the Contact page and get in touch!", "button_title": "Join Now!", "button_link": null, "button_external_link": "https://dsausa.nationbuilder.com/join"}}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "How Do Membership and Dues Work?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

DSA is a membership-driven organization. That means that all operations, events, and campaigns are funded by our members’ dues. This ensures that DSA members are in full democratic and political control of our organization and that we are never reliant on donations or private funding. Dues start at $40 per year for the local and $45 per year for the national organization and entitle all members to organizational resources and a vote within the organization.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "What Do Dues Go Toward?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

There are two types of dues we ask our members to pay, national and local.

Local dues pay for everything you see here in Philadelphia, including facilities, equipment, special events, and campaigns. They give us the ability to support unique initiatives, organize our membership, influence politics within the greater Philadelphia area, build infrastructure, and provide meeting spaces to our members.

National dues go to DSA USA, and pay for infrastructure, campaigns, and offices. These can be paid here.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "Why Should I Become a Dues Paying Member?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Funds are crucial to our ability to function as a robust, effective chapter, and every penny counts. As much as we may wish otherwise, political organization requires money. Local dues will allow us to continue to grow, develop membership, and contribute to the overall goals of the DSA. By becoming a dues-paying member, you’re helping to prove that effective mobilization can be done democratically, without massive donations or private fundraising.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "Can I Come to Meetings if I Don’t or Can’t Afford to Pay Dues?"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Yes! Meetings are open to anyone who would like to listen in and participate in campaigns, but only National dues paying members will be able to vote on initiatives and participate in any democratically controlled mechanisms within the chapter. Essentially - National dues are the formal requirement for DSA membership and local dues enable us to effectively operate at the local level. We really do rely on this to fund our organization so we encourage everyone to pay in, but we’ll never turn you away.

"}]

[{"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE I Name"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The name of the Local shall be the Philadelphia Local of the Democratic Socialists of America, a not-for-profit organization, also known as Philly DSA.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE II Purpose"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "The Philadelphia Local of the Democratic Socialists of America seeks to facilitate the transition to a truly democratic and socialist society, one in which the means/resources of production are democratically and socially controlled.

DSA rejects an economic order based solely on private profit, alienated labor, gross inequalities of wealth and power, discrimination based on race and sex, and brutality and violence in defense of the status quo.

DSA envisions a humane social order based on popular control of resources and production, economic planning, equitable distribution, gender and racial equality, and non-oppressive relationships.

Our conception of socialism is a profoundly democratic one. It is rooted in the belief that human beings should be free to develop to their fullest potential, that public policies should be determined not by wealth but by popular participation, and that individual liberties should be carefully safeguarded. It is committed to a freedom of speech that does not recoil from dissent, to a freedom to organize independent trade unions, women’s groups, political parties, and other formations -- recognizing these as essential bulwarks against the dangers of an intrusive state. It is committed to a freedom of religion that acknowledges the rights of those for whom spiritual concerns are central.

We are socialists because we are developing a concrete strategy for achieving that vision. In the present, we are building a visible socialist presence within the broad democratic left. In the long run, we hope to build a majority movement capable of making democratic socialism a reality in the United States. Our strategy acknowledges the class structure of the U.S. society. This class structure means that there is a basic conflict of interest between those sectors with enormous economic power and the vast majority of the population.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE III Membership"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
Section 1. Membership

Members of the Philadelphia Local DSA, also known as Philly DSA, will be those individuals whose dues to national DSA are paid in full, who reside and/or work in the Philadelphia area. It will be the responsibility of members to approve policies and guidelines for the operation of the local chapter, to elect delegates to the national convention, to vote on matters related to national policy, and to make recommendations on issues and other matters to the National Political Committee of DSA.

Section 2. Removal of Members

If a full member is found to be in substantial disagreement with the principles or policies of national DSA, or if they are found to be consistently engaging in undemocratic or disruptive behavior, the Local may vote to expel them from DSA. In order for such a finding to be made, another DSA member must formally prefer written charges against the member in question to the Local Steering Committee, which shall set the date of a Local meeting for deliberations on the charges. The member in question must receive a copy of the written charges and notice of the meeting a minimum of two weeks before that meeting takes place. Expulsion of a member or affiliate member requires a two-thirds vote of the Local meeting. An expelled full member may appeal to the National Political Committee of DSA.

Section 3. Dues

The Local chapter may establish a Local pledge system of voluntary donations for its members.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE IV Local Meetings"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
Section 1.  Local Convention
The Local will hold a minimum of one Local Convention every two years, and all members of the Local will receive three weeks written (or electronic mail) notice and an agenda of the Local Convention.  The Local Convention will elect Local officers and may adopt an annual budget.  In general, it is the highest legislative body of the Local.
Section 2.  General Meetings
The Local will hold General Meetings at least four times annually, the time and place of which shall be set in a schedule published and distributed by the Local Steering Committee. The General Meetings will set Local policy and work priorities, and will include political education sessions.
 
The Local Steering Committee will set the agenda for General Meetings.
Section 3.  Emergency Meetings
The Local Steering Committee may call an Emergency Meeting of the Local on five days notice when an urgent and important matter requires deliberation.
Section 4.  Quorum

A quorum of 20 percent of the members (but not fewer than 5 persons) is required for General or Emergency Meetings to transact business.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE V Local Officers: Powers and Duties"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
Section 1. Officers and Terms

The officers of the Local will be the two Co-Chairs, the treasurer, and up to 6 additional at-large members who form the Local Steering Committee. The term of office will be two years, and shall run from October to September or until successors are elected. At least one of the three officers must be a self-identified woman.

Section 2. Vacancies

In the event of a vacancy of any of the officers, the Steering Committee may vote to elect a new officer in replacement for the remainder of the term.

Section 3. Co-Chairs

a. The Co-Chairs will be the chief Steering officers of the Local. They will preside over Local and Steering Committee meetings or will appoint a substitute to assume the powers and duties of the presiding officers as specified in Robert’s Rules of Order. The Co-Chairs will be the official public spokespersons for the Local and will initiate such actions and policies as the Local’s general welfare may demand.

b. The Co-Chairs will be responsible also for coordinating the day-to-day operations and political work of the Local’s branches and committees.

c. The Co-Chairs will report to Local General Meetings on the business of the Steering Committee Meetings, at which time a copy of the minutes of those meetings will be available for inspection.

Section 5. Treasurer

The Treasurer will be responsible for the funds and financial records of the Local. All funds collected by the Local will be turned over to the Treasurer, who shall deposit them in a bank account under the name of the Local. In cooperation with the Secretary, the Treasurer will be responsible for ensuring that membership dues are paid up-to-date. The Treasurer will prepare the annual Local budget, and deliver the Local financial report to the General Meeting of the Local, as well as periodic progress reports as requested by the Steering Committee of the Local.

Section 6. At-Large Members.

The Local Steering Committee may elect up to six (6) At-Large Members to the Local Steering Committee as representatives of the Local and its diverse political views.

At-Large Members will be responsible for any additional duties and responsibilities that the Local Steering Committee determines are necessary, including participating in Local Committees, fundraising, developing campaigns, planning educational programming, acting as representatives of the Local, networking with other organizations or activists in the region, etc.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE VI Steering Committee"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
Section 1. Composition 

The Local Steering Committee will be composed of the Co-Chairs, treasurer, and up to 6 At-Large Members.

Section 2. Duties

a) The Steering Committee administers the affairs of the Local and oversees the implementation of the decisions of the General Meetings; it may also create policy in-between Local Conventions. It shall have the power to receive reports of any Committee and advise thereon, to call emergency meetings of the Local, and to act on any matter that requires immediate and urgent action. The Steering Committee is the regular Steering body of the Local, and thus subordinate to its Legislative bodies, the Local Convention.

b) The Local Steering Committee will be responsible for establishing program activities for the Local chapter, for proposing guidelines and policies that will subsequently be voted on by full members of DSA, and for acting on the organization’s behalf between Local meetings.

Section 3. Termination of Steering Committee Members

The Steering Committee may vote to remove a member from the committee in the event that the member is unable or unwilling to perform their duties. Grounds for termination include: missing more than two (2) Steering Committee meetings in a row, failure to participate in at least one (1) additional local ad hoc committee, mismanagement of funds, etc. The Steering Committee must notify the member in writing of the termination and may request to appeal the decision at a meeting of the full Local. Reinstatement of a terminated Steering Committee member requires a two-thirds vote of the Local meeting.

Section 4. Meetings

The meetings of the Steering Committee will be held at the call of the Co-Chairs at such intervals as may be determined by a prior Steering Committee Meeting or by consultation with any three members of the Steering Committee. All members of the Steering Committee must (ordinarily) be given four days oral or written notice of regular Steering Committee Meetings; a 24-hour notice may be given under special emergency circumstances.

Section 5. Quorum

A quorum of five members of the Steering Committee is required for the transaction of Steering Committee business.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE VII Branches"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
Section 1. Definition 

A branch is a subgroup of the Local consisting of at least five full members in good standing with national DSA. Branches may be defined by geography, work site, constituency (e.g., labor, minority, feminist), or area of political work (e.g., peace action, environmental movement). The chairs of branches will hold membership on the Local Steering Committee.

Section 2. Youth Sections

Branches established on college campuses and consisting of students will be called Local Youth Sections. Youth Sections must have at least five full members in good standing with national DSA. The chairs of Local Youth Sections will hold membership on the Local Steering Committee.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE VIII Committees"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
Section 1. Duration 

The Local will have Ad Hoc Committees, which will exist for a limited and explicit duration. Ad Hoc Committees may be established by a vote of full members at a General Meeting of the Local or by the Steering Committee.

Section 2. Duties

Chairs of Ad Hoc Committees will keep the Steering Committee and the General Meetings of the Local informed on the activities of the committee.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE IX Delegates to National, Regional, and State Bodies"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
Section 1. Convention 

Local delegates and alternates to the National Convention will be elected by the Local Steering Committee. Elections for the National Convention delegation shall be held on the schedule announced by the national organization.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE X Prohibited Activity"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Philadelphia Local shall not engage in activity prohibited by the IRS guidelines established for 501 (c) 4 organizations or similar rules established by the state of Pennsylvania; Nor shall the local engage in any activity prohibited by resolutions adopted by DSA’s National Convention or DSA’s National Political Committee.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE XI Nominations and Recalls"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
Section 1. Nominations Committee

A three-person Nominations Committee shall be established at least one month prior to every election by vote of a Local Convention. It shall solicit and receive nominations for the positions to be elected.

Section 2. Nominations Process

Nominations for Local officers and delegates to the National Convention shall be opened 30 days before and closed 5 days prior to the Local Convention. The call for nominations shall be announced to full members of DSA in advance of the General Meeting.

The local Steering Committee will release an application for nominees that must be submitted to the Steering Committee no less than 5 days prior to the Local Convention for candidates to be eligible for the election.

No member may join the Steering Committee until they have been a dues paying member and participated in the local for 6 consecutive months.

Section 3. Uncontested Positions

If a position is uncontested, the nominee will be declared elected by acclamation.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE XII Amendments"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

Proposed amendments to these Bylaws must be made by written resolution, endorsed by five members of the Local chapter of DSA, and submitted to the Steering Committee a month in advance of a General Meeting. The Steering Committee is required to provide the Local membership with two weeks’ written notice of the proposed amendments. The amendment must be approved by a majority vote of a General Meeting.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE XIII Local Dues"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The Local reserves the right to collect quarterly dues from full members, in addition to the dues paid by members to DSA nationally. The amount of local will be voted on in the budget during the Local Convention or set by the Steering Committee. Local dues will be collected at the General Meeting.

"}, {"type": "subhead", "value": "ARTICLE XIV Rules of the Local"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "
Section 1. Rules 

The Rules contained in Robert’s Rules of Order, Newly Revised, shall govern this Local in cases to which they are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent with these Bylaws. Consensus decision-making is desirable where feasible, but meetings must submit to Robert’s Rules of Order upon the request of a member.

Section 2. Action Out of Order

Any action taken by an officer or member of the Local in contravention of these Bylaws is null and void.

"}, {"type": "paragraph", "value": "

The above bylaws were adopted on June 30th, 2016

"}]
